awd_titl_txt: SHF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Predictive Modeling for Next-generation Heterogeneous System Design
awd_abstract_narration:
With semiconductor scaling reaching physical limits, performance and power consumption are ever more critical aspects in the design of emerging computer systems. Fast and accurate design models and tools are critical to support future computer system designers in evaluating design options before they can be built. Traditional simulation-based or analytical models are often too slow or inaccurate to effectively support design processes. This project instead develops novel machine learning-based, predictive methodologies to rapidly estimate the performance and power consumption of future generation products at early design stages using observations obtained on commercially available silicon today. Such techniques will allow efficient design cycles ensuring that the next-generation computing infrastructure meets the needs and expectations of consumers and continues to meet them over the product lifecycle. Along with research activities, course material on predictive modeling will be integrated into the university courses taught by the investigators, technology will be transferred to industrial partners through training and tutorials, and tools and models developed in this project will be released as open source software. In addition to training of graduate students, emphasis will be paid to undergraduate student training, towards including federally recognized under-represented groups, training of STEM teachers, and to run summer code camps to increase access for middle school and high school students. 

This project specifically investigates use of advanced machine learning techniques for prediction of power and performance of any machine based on hardware-dependent and independent application characteristics obtained by running on any existing other machine, focusing on large-scale data center and accelerator technologies, namely multi-core CPUs, GPUs and FPGAs. Specific research tasks include the investigation of: (1) fast and accurate models for system designers and system programmers to perform rapid, early hardware and software design space exploration; (2) fast online prediction models that can be integrated into modern operating systems and virtual machine; and (3) fast yet accurate model training procedures that can create new predictive models while applications run. This research is expected to also allow semiconductor companies to better understand the scenarios under which predictive modeling is sufficiently accurate to be deployed during an industrial design process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Models that predict system behavior before a system is built are a crucial component for any scientific or engineering discipline. In case of computer system design, programmers, architects and runtime systems of future-generation large-scale heterogeneous systems have a need for fast yet accurate models to predict and ultimately optimize key metrics such as performance or energy consumption. Traditionally, research has been focused on either simulations or analytical models to answer such design- or run-time questions. However, these approaches are often too slow or too inaccurate to support decision making for the scale of systems envisioned for the future. At the same time, with recent rapid advances in machine learning (ML), the use of ML-based approaches for modeling and prediction has created breakthroughs in many domains, and has significant potential for closing the gap between simulation-based and purely analytical or mechanistic models.

In this project, we investigated novel advanced machine learning approaches to develop predictive models that aid in computer system design, programming and runtime management. Our work has resulted in the following main contributions: (1) for computer system designers and architects, we have developed novel models and approaches that allow rapid yet accurate prediction of power and energy consumption of various heterogeneous system components, such as CPUs, GPUs and hardware accelerators before silicon is available; (2) for programmers, we have developed novel ML-based approaches that allow prediction of the performance and energy impact of different application mappings onto heterogeneous targets without the need for rewriting or porting of code; and (3) for operating and runtime systems, we have developed models that predict future short- and long-term application and system behavior such that runtime decisions can be made proactively instead of reactively.

Results of this project have demonstrated that lightweight models with low training and inference overhead are capable of predicting performance and energy metrics with high accuracy. Furthermore, applying these models to representative architectural design, application development, and runtime system scenarios has led to several advances in optimization methods for improving computer system performance and energy. We have further developed practical and general design tools and methodologies that leverage predictive models, and we have integrated such approaches into overall system design frameworks and runtime systems to make them available to a broad audience while improving applicability in real-world use scenarios specifically in the context of large-scale system design.

In addition to over 30 conference and journal publications including 2 Best Paper Awards and nominations as well as invited book chapters and presentations, this award has resulted in a number of tools, benchmark suites and ML datasets that have been publicly released in open-source form for use by industry or other researchers. Throughout the project, a number of industry collaborations have been established with joint publications and transfer of technology into commercial products. Furthermore, the project has fully or partially supported one undergraduate, two M.S. and four Ph.D. students towards their degrees (including one female Ph.D. student originally from Latin America) who have subsequently taken on positions in academia or industry.   

Overall, this project has significantly expanded the scope of predictive modeling and investigated deployment scenarios for novel predictive models and tools to specifically assist computer system designers, application programmers and operating and runtime system developers of complex emerging computer systems. Results of this work have the potential to significantly impact the way computing systems of the future are designed. With technology scaling reaching limits, future gains in compute capabilities will require applications and architectures to be tightly co-designed and co-optimized. Fast and accurate models to support design space exploration at hitherto infeasible scales are critical in sustaining evolution and growth of computing technology that has had enormous social implications over the last thirty years.
